name: BundleConfig

id.description: unique id used for compatibility purposes

slug.description: kebab-case of the name, should be unique

name.description: Human readable name of the monorepo (A kebab-case version of this will be used as root foldername)

dependencies.description:
Generated, private by default. If they're already here, uses private/public setting as given.

When generating, removes the ones that are not dependencies (of dependencies) of your standalone apps

docsRelativeFolderPath.description:
optional. Could also find the main file from here and use that as README.md

Must be a relative path from project root

readmeRelativeFilePath.description:
optional. path to a readme file for the monorepo root.

If not given, and if you did provide a path for docs, the main docs intro file will be taken

Must be a relative path from project  root

foldersFromRepo.description:
if given, it will fetch these folders from the repo and paste them in the bundle whenever the bundle is generated

can be handy if you're working with someone else...

branchName.description: specify the branch to use of your git repo (defaults to "main")

schema.description:
Time

Time can be stored in various ways but in my experience it is, again, best to keep it simple and just have one way to store time. I can think about this for hours, but my intuition goes towards using the same format as Date.now() because it is a very small format and is easy to read.

It is the amount of ms since 1970.

I could argue to store it in seconds since 1970 since there are few applications of doing ms, but maybe we do, and it's just 30% bigger. No problem.

Therefore, let's store all time values in the format Date.now()

Time

Time can be stored in various ways but in my experience it is, again, best to keep it simple and just have one way to store time. I can think about this for hours, but my intuition goes towards using the same format as Date.now() because it is a very small format and is easy to read.

It is the amount of ms since 1970.

I could argue to store it in seconds since 1970 since there are few applications of doing ms, but maybe we do, and it's just 30% bigger. No problem.

Therefore, let's store all time values in the format Date.now()

Time

Time can be stored in various ways but in my experience it is, again, best to keep it simple and just have one way to store time. I can think about this for hours, but my intuition goes towards using the same format as Date.now() because it is a very small format and is easy to read.

It is the amount of ms since 1970.

I could argue to store it in seconds since 1970 since there are few applications of doing ms, but maybe we do, and it's just 30% bigger. No problem.

Therefore, let's store all time values in the format Date.now()

Time

Time can be stored in various ways but in my experience it is, again, best to keep it simple and just have one way to store time. I can think about this for hours, but my intuition goes towards using the same format as Date.now() because it is a very small format and is easy to read.

It is the amount of ms since 1970.

I could argue to store it in seconds since 1970 since there are few applications of doing ms, but maybe we do, and it's just 30% bigger. No problem.

Therefore, let's store all time values in the format Date.now()
unique id used for compatibility purposes
use this for any identifier that's not an Id-type. Usually this is a kebab-case version of a written text, but it can also be a file path, for example.
Human readable name of the monorepo (A kebab-case version of this will be used as root foldername)
all currently supported languages
This type can specify a frontend and backend that belong to each other. it doesn't include all operations that the ui or server are dependent on, they are calculated separately
any operation names that are not necesarily dependencies of the named front-back bundle but still need to be available.

if public, everything will be kept

if private, src and todo will be removed from bundle, unless it's a ui-es6 operation, because src is needed then. In that case, only "todo" will be deleted.
(optional) main shared ui package of the frontend
which app shell(s) or app operations are there for the frontend?
operation name for server, if this UI is connected to one
if there is a ui and it has a web-shell, and it is deployed somewhere into production, add the deployed domain here.

if the server is to be deployed, specify the server-env package that exposes the server environment variables (JSON) to the ui

By default, uses "server-env" operation, which simply exposes a configuration env.json file. the generation of the bundle will set the "remoteServer" key in this env.json to the "productionApiUrl" so the deployed version can reach the api
if there is one, it should be specified here (without trailing slash)

if this is provided, all endpoints require this auth token to be provided, or the endpoints do not work

if you wish to have a more extensive authentication method for your endpoints, make sure to create your own auth layer

Generated, private by default. If they're already here, uses private/public setting as given.

When generating, removes the ones that are not dependencies (of dependencies) of your standalone apps

if public, everything will be kept

if private, src and todo will be removed from bundle, unless it's a ui-es6 operation, because src is needed then. In that case, only "todo" will be deleted.

later this could be known by the frontend so it will render a ui to select a folder

We need to figure out how we can know all type types in between when getting the type definition schema, not only the final type. If I'm lucky there is a way to find it as a #ref in a consistent way.

if given, it will fetch these folders from the repo and paste them in the bundle whenever the bundle is generated

can be handy if you're working with someone else...

push (default): take needed information from project and push to bundle (removing the existing info)

pullReplace: pull bundle and keep its information intact, not taking anything new from the OS, replacing all the information we had from these models in the OS

pullMerge: pull bundle and use its information in conjunction with the information we had in the OS. This option will merge both information sources, removing duplicate IDs

NB: Later we may want to define this setting on a per-model basis!
specify the branch to use of your git repo (defaults to "main")

name: CreatedFirstAt
description: in some cases, data can be created before it was created in our system. In this case, use CreatedFirstAt if this information is important.

typeDefinition.description: in some cases, data can be created before it was created in our system. In this case, use CreatedFirstAt if this information is important.

name: Slug
description: use this for any identifier that's not an Id-type. Usually this is a kebab-case version of a written text, but it can also be a file path, for example.

typeDefinition.description: use this for any identifier that's not an Id-type. Usually this is a kebab-case version of a written text, but it can also be a file path, for example.

simplifiedSchema.description: use this for any identifier that's not an Id-type. Usually this is a kebab-case version of a written text, but it can also be a file path, for example.

name: FrontBackBundle
description: This type can specify a frontend and backend that belong to each other. it doesn't include all operations that the ui or server are dependent on, they are calculated separately

operations.description: any operation names that are not necesarily dependencies of the named front-back bundle but still need to be available.

uiOperationName.description: (optional) main shared ui package of the frontend

appShellOperationNames.description: which app shell(s) or app operations are there for the frontend?

serverOperationName.description: operation name for server, if this UI is connected to one

productionWebUrl.description: if there is a ui and it has a web-shell, and it is deployed somewhere into production, add the deployed domain here.

envOperationName.description:
if the server is to be deployed, specify the server-env package that exposes the server environment variables (JSON) to the ui

By default, uses "server-env" operation, which simply exposes a configuration env.json file. the generation of the bundle will set the "remoteServer" key in this env.json to the "productionApiUrl" so the deployed version can reach the api

productionApiUrl.description: if there is one, it should be specified here (without trailing slash)

endpointsAuthToken.description:
if this is provided, all endpoints require this auth token to be provided, or the endpoints do not work

if you wish to have a more extensive authentication method for your endpoints, make sure to create your own auth layer

typeDefinition.description: This type can specify a frontend and backend that belong to each other. it doesn't include all operations that the ui or server are dependent on, they are calculated separately

if you wish to have a more extensive authentication method for your endpoints, make sure to create your own auth layer

name: InformationStrategy
description:
push (default): take needed information from project and push to bundle (removing the existing info)

pullReplace: pull bundle and keep its information intact, not taking anything new from the OS, replacing all the information we had from these models in the OS

pullMerge: pull bundle and use its information in conjunction with the information we had in the OS. This option will merge both information sources, removing duplicate IDs

NB: Later we may want to define this setting on a per-model basis!

pullReplace: pull bundle and keep its information intact, not taking anything new from the OS, replacing all the information we had from these models in the OS

NB: Later we may want to define this setting on a per-model basis!

push (default): take needed information from project and push to bundle (removing the existing info)

pullReplace: pull bundle and keep its information intact, not taking anything new from the OS, replacing all the information we had from these models in the OS

pullMerge: pull bundle and use its information in conjunction with the information we had in the OS. This option will merge both information sources, removing duplicate IDs

NB: Later we may want to define this setting on a per-model basis!

name: Id
description:
azAZ09 characters are easy to copy and provide 62 characters. the goal of an id is to be unique.

the advantage of a random id compared to an numeric id starting with 1 with auto increment is that you can set them up decentralised.

the change of duplicate ids gets bigger once you make them shorter the change of finding an existing id gets bigger once you make them shorter

An Id with 12 characters would provide 3.22e21 combinations.

What is the change of duplicate ids? This depends on the amount of identifyable items in the data What is the change of guessing an id? This depends on speed of a brute force attack and the amount of available datapoints. If you can guess 10000 times per second, you can make 864.000.000 guesses. A billion guesses on a dataset of a billion datapoints yields 3226 correct ids on average.

Why make an id short? I don't know if there's an important reason.

All in all, I think we should make ids 24 characters by default. This would make it very easy to store, yet, with more than E42 combinations, make it nearly impossible to get duplication or brute force hits.

An id would look like this:

``` {  "id": "sk2EcW9AkZpksk2EcW9AkZpk" } ```

Looks good to me! Don't think about it and just keep it simple. We can always migrate later to a bigger amount, but I don't see good reason to keep it smaller than this.
